item.title: Russia’s Annexation Claim Is News to Residents of Lyman, Ukraine
item.description: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A badly damaged building in Lyman, a strategic rail hub.

item.title: The Kremlin, after trumpeting annexation, admits it doesn’t know where the borders are.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian running on a destroyed bridge over the Oskil River, in Kupiansk, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: They Legitimized the Myth of a Stolen Election — and Reaped the Rewards
item.description: On the day the Capitol was attacked, 139 Republicans in the House voted to dispute the Electoral College count. This is how they got there.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick and Mike McIntire
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg
item.media:description: An aide inspected the official tally to certify the vote hours after rioters had stormed Congress to disrupt the transfer of power.

item.title: How a Tiny Elections Company Became a Conspiracy Theory Target
item.description: Election deniers catapulted a Michigan firm with just 21 U.S. employees to the center of unfounded voter fraud claims, exposing it to vicious threats.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election deniers have started to focus more on companies and people with less central roles in the voting process.

item.title: Maggie Haberman Talks About Reporting on Donald Trump
item.description: He often utters falsehoods, but his speaking style is more strategic than it sometimes seems. Listen for the first time to audio clips from an interview with Maggie Haberman.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump in Warren, Mich., this weekend.

item.title: Truss, in Reversal, Drops Plan to Cut U.K. Tax Rate on High Earners
item.description: The announcement was a major capitulation by the government after the tax cuts it announced roiled financial markets and drew widespread criticism.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain, center, has been forced to change course during her Conservative Party’s showpiece annual conference in Birmingham, England.

item.title: How the U.K. Finance Minister Came to Ignore Finance Experts
item.description: Kwasi Kwarteng, the chancellor of the Exchequer, faces widespread anger over the tax cuts he and Liz Truss have pushed, but their history of dismissing the economic establishment goes back years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a series of tax cuts that sent the markets spiraling.

item.title: Less Turnover, Smaller Raises: Hot Job Market May Be Losing Its Sizzle
item.description: Unemployment is low, and hiring is strong. But there are signs that frenzied turnover and rapid wage growth are abating.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Sarah Rice for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Biggby Coffee store in Sterling Heights, Mich. Until recently, staffing shortages at some locations were so severe that many of the chain’s 300-plus stores had to close early some days.

item.title: The Story Behind DeSantis’s Migrant Flights to Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: Asylum seekers in Texas were recruited for the flights by a woman who appeared to be a former Army counterintelligence agent. “We were tricked,” one migrant said.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval, Miriam Jordan, Patricia Mazzei and J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of men from Venezuela outside the Migrant Resource Center in San Antonio in September.

item.title: Knocking on Every Door, Rescuers Search Fort Myers Beach After Ian
item.description: A search-and-rescue team set out to account for every person left on the hurricane-battered island — even if that meant breaking down doors.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Jason Andrew

item.title: On Sanibel Island, a Search for Stranded Residents Slogs On
item.description: About 200 households did not leave ahead of Hurricane Ian. Rescue teams are tracking down the stranded and evacuating them — if they are willing.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Johnny Milano
item.media:description: A neighbor watched as the Stasi family evacuated Sanibel, Fla.

item.title: Biden Will Visit Puerto Rico to Survey Storm Damage
item.description: Utility companies are still working to restore power to thousands of customers on the island nearly two weeks after Hurricane Fiona made landfall.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Alejandro Granadillo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Hurricane Fiona caused widespread flooding in Puerto Rico.

item.title: Bolsonaro Outperforms Polls and Forces Runoff Against Lula in Brazil’s Presidential Election
item.description: The two political titans will face off again later this month in a race widely seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

item.title: A 95-Square-Foot Tokyo Apartment: ‘I Wouldn’t Live Anywhere Else’
item.description: Meet the young Japanese who have decided to live in a shoe box.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yugo Kinoshita, 19, in his apartment in Tokyo.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine Is Awarded to Svante Pääbo
item.description: The Swedish geneticist was honored for his work in sequencing the genome of the Neanderthal, an extinct relative of present-day humans.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller

item.title: Kim Kardashian to Pay $1.26 Million to Settle SEC Charges Over Crypto Promotion
item.description: The S.E.C. said Ms. Kardashian did not disclose she had been paid to promote a crypto token sold by EthereumMax.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Kardashian at the Met Gala in May.

item.title: What We Learned From Week 4 in the N.F.L.
item.description: The Steelers are testing out a new quarterback, Baker Mayfield is struggling to hit an already low bar, and Geno Smith is cooking in the new-look Seahawks offense.
item.dc:creator: Derrik Klassen
item.media:credit: Philip G. Pavely/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kenny Pickett, the Steelers’ 2022 first-round pick, threw three interceptions in his first regular season appearance.

item.title: Is There Anything That Will Make the ‘Former Guy’ Go Away?
item.description: Pardon politics make for strange bedfellows.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin/Getty Images
item.media:description: Apparently not.

item.title: America Has a Ginni Thomas Problem
item.description: Clarence and Ginni Thomas are Mr. and Mrs. Mutiny.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images

item.title: Two Kids. One Pony. Hundreds of Miles to Montreal’s Expo 67.
item.description: Two brothers from the Boston suburbs set out on an improbable journey to Montreal’s Expo 67 by hoof.
item.media:credit: Eric Stange

item.title: The Supreme Court Isn’t Listening, and It’s No Secret Why
item.description: A court that does not keep the public’s trust cannot perform its critical role in American government.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times

item.title: There Is a Tax That Could Help With Inflation
item.description: The case for a progressive levy on consumption.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times

item.title: These 2022 Mets Are Already Amazing
item.description: My son has autism. He doesn’t have a sport he regularly watches, and I wanted to remedy that.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen A. O’Brien

item.title: Lights Out, America! (Songbirds Are Counting on Us.)
item.description: Up to a billion birds die in window strikes every year. But the best way to make the migration seasons safer overall is also the easiest.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Douglas Gochfeld

item.title: A U.S. ‘Ships Act’ Would Break China’s Control of the Seas
item.description: China’s shipping dominance could bring the U.S. to its knees in a conflict.
item.dc:creator: Michael Roberts
item.media:credit: Yannis Kolesidis/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A China Ocean Shipping Company container carrier at a port in Greece.

item.title: The Latino Voters Who Could Decide the Midterms
item.description: What a Times poll revealed about how a key voting bloc sees both parties ahead of November’s elections.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Diana Nguyen, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Nina Feldman, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dani Bernal, born in Bolivia and raised in Miami, described herself as an independent who’s in line with Democrats on social issues but Republicans on the economy.

item.title: Modern Love Gay Dad
item.description: A man comes out to his wife — and breaks apart their family. Fifteen years later, we check back in.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: How to Strengthen Your Bones and Reduce Osteoporosis Risk
item.description: A new study predicts hip fractures will nearly double worldwide by 2050. Here’s how to avoid them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Matt Chase

item.title: It’s Time to Take Democrats’ Chances in the House Seriously
item.description: No, they are not favored. But the notion of retaining the chamber is not as far-fetched as it once was.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy, before the memorial service last month for Queen Elizabeth II in Washington. Republicans are favored to retake the House.

item.title: Why Polio, Once Eliminated, Is Testing N.Y. Health Officials
item.description: Health officials are facing a number of obstacles to containing polio as it continues to circulate in New York State and threatens to become endemic.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pop-up vaccination clinic for the polio vaccine was opened in Rockland County after a case was discovered there.

item.title: Sacheen Littlefeather, Activist Who Rejected Brando’s Oscar, Dies at 75
item.description: The actress was booed at the Academy Awards in 1973 after she refused the best actor award on Marlon Brando’s behalf in protest of Hollywood’s depictions of Native Americans.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Ms. Littlefeather and Mr. Brando had become friends through her neighbor, the director Francis Ford Coppola.

item.title: French Feminist Rabbi Captivates Multifaith Crowds With Musings on Mortality
item.description: With Paris locked down over Passover, a rabbi started holding weekly talks over Zoom about Jewish texts. Thousands have tuned in to hear her reflections on death. “She is my rabbi,” said an atheist.
item.dc:creator: Julia Lieblich
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbi Delphine Horvilleur, center left, at a Bar Mitzvah ceremony.

item.title: How Hard Should Your Workout Be?
item.description: Every strenuous exercise involves some mixture of suffering and pleasure. The key to sticking with it is getting the balance right.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hutchinson
item.media:credit: Sean Dong

item.title: F.D.A. Moves to Change ‘Healthy’ Food Definition
item.description: Salmon is in; sugary yogurt is out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times

item.title: Hair Loss After Covid: What to Know
item.description: Increased shedding after illness is not unusual. The good news is that it’s most likely temporary.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Paige Vickers

item.title: A Shining Moment of Pan-African Promise in a New Book
item.description: Marilyn Nance was 23 when she photographed FESTAC ’77, the immense gathering of Black artists in Nigeria. In ‘Last Day in Lagos,’ she shares her archive.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Mitter
item.media:credit: Lelanie Foster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marilyn Nance, at right, the photographer and author of “Last Day in Lagos,” which was edited by Oluremi C. Onabanjo, below left, seen at Nance’s home in Brooklyn.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
